body: +1. Even if it's not fully semver, I would be interested to know if there will potentially be breaking changes without a major version bump.

Personally I don't have a problem with version numbers like `v32.15.0`. I understand it's messy from a general user standpoint (i.e. If this was Atom and not Electron) but I think most developers understand what this means.

Anyway, thanks for defining this. Even if Electron doesn't follow semver, it's good to know what to expect and I understand that releasing Electron 2.0 (because of the new Node major version) a few days after the big 1.0 milestone might feel a bit odd.

Agree the comment from @zcbenz above should go into the docs. Having a custom semantic meaning for versions that looks like semver but is actually something else is kind of misleading, so user education becomes more important.

> I think the root problem is we are adding new too fast, and publishing new releases too frequently.

You can never publish new releases too quickly. Please don't change this. If you hold them back and then submit new releases less frequently, it's going to be very painful for people to upgrade and pin down where problems are. Frequent releases makes it really easy to track down what's causing the problem.

> Personally I don't have a problem with version numbers like v32.15.0.

Nor do I. Case in point, Chrome.

> Agree the comment from @zcbenz above should go into the docs. Having a custom semantic meaning for versions that looks like semver but is actually something else is kind of misleading, so user education becomes more important.

I also agree with this. It is a bit misleading, so clearly documenting the meaning of the version numbers is important.
Y'all are super right, I just added a little document summarizing the rules and recommendations.
+1 to semver. Then people everybody knows what updates mean. If the downside is only having version numbers like v32.15.0, I'm not sure many developers would have a problem with that.

Why not this policy instead:
- **Major bump:** Electron API breakage, Major Node upgrades
- **Minor bump:** New features, Major Chrome upgrades (these are never breaking)
- **Patch bump:** Bug fixes

This is intuitive to the Node.js/npm community and wouldn't make the version v32.x.x too quickly, since Major Node upgrades happen only every 6 months.

- semver is very good for machines and developers as an agreed-upon protocol to follow.
- for many humans, it is very good be clear when _very drastic_ **product** changes happen ("v1" to "v2", etc)

Re: "version numbers like v32.15.0", i understand and agree with the problem of saying "Electron v32" (we have it in the Go and multi-language communities). Consider this or something similar: 

> "[vanity semver](https://github.com/jbenet/random-ideas/issues/35)": `<vanity>.<major>.<minor>.<patch>`, where `<vanity>` is for marketing and the rest is for API changes.
> 
> Eg. `1.32.15.0` or really, "Electron v1" with package-manager friendly semver `32.15.0`.

Some very relevant notes here, but i do not mean to derail. vanity semver [discussion can happen here](https://github.com/jbenet/random-ideas/issues/35), or another thread (many, many people have suggested this kind of a thing. there's some other threads likely).
- the vanity/marketing version number is very important for end users who want to know whether this is "Thing alpha (v0)", "Thing stable (v1)", or "Totally new, redone Thing (v2)".
- **semver is very important for clear understanding of APIs and compatibility in packaging / deployments / package managers.**
- adding another number is not a big deal, given how big version numbers for browsers are in general.
- can package all vanity under same semver, if  `<major>` remains monotonic, so `1.32.15.0`, `2.33.0.0`. can get packaged under semvers `32.15.0` and `33.0.0` just fine.
- or if you _really_ want to roll `<major>` back to 0 when making a `<vanity>` upgrade, make `<vanity>` part of the package name, eg `electron-prebuilt` and `electron-prebuilt-v2` once you make a marketing break.

> the vanity/marketing version number is very important for end users 

Do users care that they're using OS X 10.11.4? They're using "Yosemite" or "El Capitan". Version numbers are for developers.

> Major Chrome upgrades (these are never breaking)

This hasn't been our experience, upgrading just Chrome can definitely break your app
Btw, i think @feross's suggestion here https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/5561#issuecomment-219823045 is a really good idea for Electron.

If we were to change the version number scheme, I propose that the major version follows the Chrome version directly, so we would immediately jump to `v50.0.0`, and that we only do node updates during Chrome updates. This would follow Semver rules as well as have the bonus side-effect of being able to tell the Chrome version from the Electron version.

This has the side-effect that means that breaking Electron API changes have to happen alongside a Chrome release, but tbh I consider that a Feature Not A Bug :)

> @paulcbetts Upgrading just Chrome can definitely break your app

Sure, but those changes also break the web -- real, deployed websites -- without any notice. Chrome is pretty conservative about that and usually only do it to bring Chrome in line with the spec. Examples: Chrome deprecations in [M49](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2016/02/chrome-49-deprecations) and [M50](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2016/03/chrome-50-deprecations). (This means that, in my proposal, minor bumps would technically carry a small risk of breakage from Chrome.)

> @paulcbetts I propose that the major version follows the Chrome version directly

This is better, because at least it's semver. But it has the effect of making most major version bumps "noise" since most Chrome updates don't break anything. Ah, tradeoffs...

I think the path of least resistance is going with the current version scheme and number set while making sure new features are minor bumps and bug fixes are patch bumps, which is what most users expect. I think the question of how to manage Chrome and Node upgrades is a little out of the scope of this issue, however I will say I would not advise jumping from 1.x to 50.x 😉
Good point, @ungoldman. That's what @mafintosh's original issue was about -- new features ending up in a patch release.

> Sure, but those changes also break the web -- real, deployed websites -- without any notice. Chrome is pretty conservative about that and usually only do it to bring Chrome in line with the spec.

From a web perspective I'd totally agree, but from the actual implementation perspective it isn't the case. For example, at some point Chrome enabled DirectWrite by default on Windows, which meant that a certain group of people with garbage video cards went from a working app to something that was a fuzzy blurry mess.  Or for example, Chromium flags can completely change from major version to major version and if you're relying on a certain behavior, you're broken. Or in M48ish, Flash was completely deprecated, even if you tried to enable it via flags - if your app was working before, now it's :fire:
@paulcbetts Interesting, thanks for the context.

Chrome upgrades are breaking changes, every time we upgrade Chrome version there are crashes and regressions, so if we follow semver it has to bump the major version. The same goes for Node upgrades, and probably toolchain upgrades (like from Visual Studio 2013 to 2015).

The problem with following semver is, we will not be able to distinguish Electron API changes from dependencies upgrades, all of them are bumping major versions. They are two different levels of changes, you have to modify your app for Electron API changes, while you can probably just do nothing to get Chrome upgrades.

Keep current version scheme but bump minor version for new features, is nice but doesn't quite suit Electron's current situation. For most releases of Electron we are adding new features, so if we use this rule there will basically be no patch version bumps, and users will not be able to judge whether it is safe to upgrade Electron when there are minor version bumps.

If Chrome upgrades are potentially breaking changes I'd personally just bump the major version every time you upgrade Chrome in Electron. Node already follows semver so you only need to bump the major when node does. New API features are a minor bump and bug fixes a patch.
- Pros: Easy for developers to identify breaking changes + a community standard + works with npm defaults
- Cons: Potentially higher version numbers.

I don't really understand why having a higher major version number is an issue personally.

If I want to figure if it is safe to upgrade to a new major version I'll read the CHANGELOG. I already do this for Node anyway.

I disagree that Chrome/Node updates should bump the major. The difference with breaking API changes is they can be planned. Chrome/Node breaking changes are not always planned and more of a side effect. And the goal of updating them is to not break things but fix/improve things in the upstream. They are also updated quite often. Bumping the major version often I feel would degrade the importance of the major number.

Exceptions could be made if the breaking changes made by Chrome/Node are major and planned. But making them control the major with every change goes against and breaks the versioning system rather than resolving it.
The major number _has_ no importance, except to convey breaking changes from the previous one. It's semantic versioning, not sentimental versioning.

> The major number has no importance, except to convey breaking changes from the previous one. It's semantic versioning, not sentimental versioning.

The importance _is_ to convey breaking changes. And updating Chrome and and Node.js are not always breaking changes or always intended to be breaking changes. So if you bump it for a non-breaking change that isn't semantic versioning.

Sure, you'd only break it for a user-visible breaking change - but that includes ABI compatibility as well as JS features, which updating chrome and major versions of node are almost guaranteed to break.
I think this question has now been appropriately addressed in the documentation http://electron.atom.io/docs/tutorial/electron-versioning/ -- safe to close?

> safe to close?

I think so, closing this out, thanks everyone for the valuable discussion here.
